page.title: 16LEITH TITHE BARN
page.content: { LEIGH TITHE BARN The great barn was built about 700 years ago and stands to the west of Leigh Court. It is a fine example of{'building on crucks',}having eleven crucks - some still with original wooden pegs. It is sadly in need of restoration and the wattle and daub has been replaced by bricks, planking and corrugated sheeting. The red tile roof has hipped ends and is popularly reputed to extend to one acre. There are five doors, properly called{'cart {doors'.}It is approximately 40 metres long, 10 metres wide and 9 metres high. The crucks are 3.9 metres apart. Inside there is a cider press, but today the barn is used to house sheep and farm machinery.
